```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(p8105.datasets)
set.seed(1)
nyc_airbnb
```


```{r}
data("nyc_airbnb")

nyc_airbnb = 
  nyc_airbnb |> 
  mutate(stars = review_scores_location / 2) |> 
  rename(
    borough = neighbourhood_group,
    neighborhood = neighbourhood) |> 
  filter(borough != "Staten Island") |> 
  select(price, stars, borough, neighborhood, room_type)
```

Perform a regression

```{r}
fit = lm(price ~ stars + borough, data = nyc_airbnb)
```

Clean then refit

```{r}
nyc_airbnb |> 
  count(borough)

nyc_airbnb = 
  nyc_airbnb |> 
  mutate(
    borough = fct_infreq(borough),  #puts categories in order of how often they occur
    room_type = fct_infreq(room_type))

fit = lm(price ~ stars + borough, data = nyc_airbnb)
```

Look at `lm` stuff

```{r}
summary(fit)
#summary(fit)$coef
#coef(fit)
#fitted.values(fit)
```

Look at cleaner `lm` stuff
```{r}
fit |> 
  broom::tidy() |> 
  select(term, estimate, p.value) |> 
  mutate(
    term = str_replace(term, "borough", "Borough: "
                       )) |> 
  knitr::kable(digits = 3)
```

## Diagnostics 

Look at residuals and predictions.  
```{r}
nyc_airbnb |>
  modelr::add_residuals(fit) |>
  modelr::add_predictions(fit) |>
  filter(resid < 1000) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = borough, y = resid)) + geom_violin()

nyc_airbnb |>
  modelr::add_residuals(fit) |>
  modelr::add_predictions(fit) |>
  filter(resid < 1000) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = stars, y = resid)) + geom_point()
```


## Hypothesis testing
```{r}
fit |> 
  broom::tidy()
```

## What about categorical teting

```{r}
fit_alt = lm(price ~ stars + borough + room_type, data = nyc_airbnb)
fit_null = lm(price ~ stars + borough, data = nyc_airbnb)

anova(fit_null, fit_alt) |> #can compare directly because nested
  broom::tidy()
```
## Interactions vs nested data

```{r}
fit_interactions = 
  lm(price ~ stars * borough + room_type * borough, data = nyc_airbnb)


fit_interactions |> 
  broom::tidy()
```

```{r}
nyc_airbnb |> 
  filter(borough == "Brooklyn") |> 
  lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = _)  |> #_ is placeholder for dataset
  broom::tidy()

nyc_airbnb |> 
  filter(borough == "Manhattan") |> 
  lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = _)  |> #_ is placeholder for dataset
  broom::tidy()

nyc_airbnb |> 
  filter(borough == "Queens") |> 
  lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = _)  |> #_ is placeholder for dataset
  broom::tidy()

nyc_airbnb |> 
  filter(borough == "Bronx") |> 
  lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = _)  |> #_ is placeholder for dataset
  broom::tidy()

```

Write a short function

```{r}

lm_airbnb = function(df){
  lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = df)
}

nyc_airbnb |> 
  filter(borough =="Queens") |> 
  lm_airbnb() |> 
  broom::tidy()
```

Create a list of df and iterate to fit model each time

```{r}

nested_lm_results = 
nyc_airbnb |>
  nest(data = -borough) |>
  mutate(
    fits = map(data, lm_airbnb),
    results = map(fits, broom::tidy) #fitting the four models at once
    ) |> 
    select(borough, results) |> 
    unnest(results)
```

Do some untidying, get clearer results

```{r}
nested_lm_results |> 
  select(borough, term, estimate) |> 
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = term,
    values_from = estimate
  )
```

Use an anonymous function instead of `lm_airbnb`

```{r}
nest_lm_res =
  nyc_airbnb |> 
  nest(data = -borough) |> 
  mutate(
    models = map(data, \(df) lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = df)),
    results = map(models, broom::tidy)) |> 
  select(-data, -models) |> 
  unnest(results)

nest_lm_res |> 
  select(borough, term, estimate) |> 
  mutate(term = fct_inorder(term)) |> 
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = term, values_from = estimate) |> 
  knitr::kable(digits = 3)
```


More extreme example

```{r}
manhattan_analysis =
  nyc_airbnb |> 
  filter(borough == "Manhattan") |> 
  nest(data = -neighborhood) |> 
  mutate(
    fits = map(data, \(df) lm(price ~ stars + room_type, data = df)),
    results = map(fits, broom::tidy)
  ) |> 
  select(neighborhood, results) |> 
  unnest(results)
```

Make a plot 

```{r}
manhattan_analysis |>
  filter(term == "stars") |> 
  mutate(
    neighborhood = fct_reorder(neighborhood, estimate)
  ) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = neighborhood, y = estimate)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))
```
